14533111.content:
"Might as well check out the scariest place here first." Lauren said to herself as she walked boldly up to the front porch. As she approached the steps, the house seemed to have an eerie green glow around it, and the front door, with its cobra door knocker, looked so much more imposing than it had earlier. Each step up onto the porch creaked and groaned under her feet, occasionally sounding like an animal, but after a moment she was at the door and ready to enter.

"Here we go." She said, trying to calm herself, for some reason she was a little shaky and nervous, probably just nerves, not every night you go into an abandoned mansion after all. Opening the door, she stepped in and turned on her flashlight, seeing the cobwebs and old chairs and bookshelf decorating the main hall. As she started down the hall, the front door shut itself with a SLAM!!!

Jumping in surprise, Lauren turned and (thankfully) didn't see anyone there, "Must've just been the hinges, or the wind." She said to herself, her heart racing in her chest as she approached the door to try and open it, but to no avail, it was wedged shut.

"Well, guess I'll be leaving out the back door." She said as she faced the hall, her flashlight for some reason not lighting up as much as it was a second ago.

Somewhere in the mansion, the ghost of the dirty old geezer that used to own this place cackled and silently moved toward her, let the fun begin!

145331111.content:
Walking into what was obviously a living room, Lauren looked around, the book shelves were empty, the furniture had those covers over all of them, and everything was dusty. Eventually she grew bored, and decided to see just what the furniture looked like underneath those sheets.

Tearing the sheet off the couch, she was treated to a very classic looking red velvet cough with what appeared to be golden embellishments along the front and legs.

"Pretty good, what about everything else?" She's said as she removed the next sheet from a chair.

Eventually, she'd unveiled all the furniture in the room, and it all stuck to that same theme: red with gold decorations.

"Well, time to AAHHH!!!" She screamed, one of the sheets was standing in front of her!

Tearing the sheet off, she was relieved to see a coat hanger, not anyone trying to stalk her or anything.

"Well, that was a heart attack I didn't need." She said as she headed down the hall, trying to calm herself as she went. From where she stood, the hall seemed to go on forever, with doors on either side. Walking down the hall, she noticed that there were a lot of paintings on the wall, each of them either a landscape or a naked woman. "The old owner of this place must've been a perv." She giggled to herself.

As she walked down the hall, she failed to notice that her jeans had been unbuttoned and unzipped, and her walking (combined with the ghost) was slowly working them down her hips, the top of her pink panties already showing on either hip.

As Lauren walked down the hall, she saw a door with a silver gilded doorknob, thinking the room must be special, she opened the door. Expecting to see something that a rich man would store away or something else that would break the monotony, she was disappointed when all she saw was a study.

"Bummer." She said to herself, walkingup to the bookshelf to see what books were there. But as she read each row of books, her jeans dropped bit by bit down her legs. As she neared the bottom of the bookshelf, her jeans had by now cleared her bottom and were piling up around her feet.

"Man, the old guy that lived her must've been so boring. Nothing exciting in this place!" Lauren said, frustrated, as she left the study, not noticing her jeans in a pile at the foot of the bookshelf.

Now, standing in the hallway sans pants, her pink panties out in the open, Lauren looked around, beating on whether or not to see what another room had, or see how far the hall goes, and check the rooms on the way back.

Heading out into the hall with her jeans still on the flor, Lauren walked down to the next door, opening it slowly, the creaking echoing across the house and adding a touch on trepidation to out girl here. Briefly her flashlight flickered, and then she could see the bottom of the box, empty.

Closing the box, Lauren failed to notice that her grey tank top had slid off her and into the box, leaving her with only her matching pink bra and panties and her shoes and socks as her clothing.

Heading out into the hall, did she check another room, or see how far the hall went?

15.content:
Not everyone goes out on Halloween night. Some have other obligations, reasons to stay home, or stay at work. Others make the choice to avoid the holiday spirit; out of fear, laziness, or a general lack of enjoyment for the holiday. Pity or turn up your nose at the as you will; it's only one might, after all.

Still, even those who don't actively partake in the festivities can find themselves swept away in a wave of fear or thrills; for their lack of a costume, some unlucky sap is going to end up stripped naked on the most nightmarish of nights, blood pumping and heart racing whether they want it or not.

It probably won't improve their opinion of Halloween much, will it?
15.title: Stuck Inside

choices: The door bell rang.
The power went out.
His home phone rings.
151.content:
October 31st, a day of scares, sweets, and silly outfits. Outside, the night was dark and clear, the moon shining brightly down onto the streets below. People went from door to door, house to house, filling their bags and containers with various bits of candy. From goblins to princesses, witches and ghosts to cowboys and superheroes, they were all enjoying the frightening festival to the fullest.

In one house, sitting at the far end of a cul-de-sac, Jason Crane sat watching some low-budget horror movie. With all the lights on, a bowl of popcorn in his lap, and his phone in his hands. He'd hoped to just enjoy a night alone, but his friends had hoped for something else, going by the texts they had been sending him.

u sure you wont come? He read on the screen.

Yeah. Stop asking, he texted back.

just one year wont kill you

still not going

if ur worried about that while skeleton thing noone even remembers that

And it was then that, Jason turned his cellphone off. If Amanda had hoped to get him out on Halloween, reminding him of the reason he was still inside, and had in fact spent the past few years spending Halloween inside, was not the way to do it. He'd been 13, the last time he'd gone out on Halloween. A little old for trick or treating, maybe, but not too old that he was looked down upon. All he really wanted was one more year of it, and then he'd be content to take the first steps into young adulthood.

He'd dressed up in a body suit with bones drawn on, a spooky skeleton wandering from door to door. Of course, one family had taken their dog out with them for the night, and this dog really, really loved bones. So, it was understandable that he'd get a little excited once he saw Jason. Ultimately, it wouldn't have been so bad, if they been walking by a house party. Between the flimsy fabric, the canine's sharp canines, and the riled up, raucous laughter of the onlooking party goers, any find memories of Halloween Jason had were eclipsed by a the complete embarrassment of being stripped in front of a crowd. So, no, he didn't like to go out on Halloween any more.

Of course, he'd only told that story to a select few people. Most people had forgotten, but Jason never could. His friends had been disappointed, though understanding, but it seemed like they were at their limit; being seniors and 18 years old now meant they'd probably being going separate ways for college, and they wanted to enjoy at least one Halloween with him. But still he refused. He felt bad, but he was content to celebrate in his own way. Alone. Fully dressed and in normal, hard to tear clothing.

He leaned back with a sigh, sinking into the cushions of the couch. The movie he was watching was pretty bad, actually, but he was fine to keep on watching it, when...

1512.content:
Marissa walked out into the rain, a flashlight her only friend-- the others having long since been murdered. She waved the flashlight around wildly, knowing at any moment, a hockey-mask-wearing-maniac could step out of the shadows, silently stalking after her as she flew to safety, away from the log cabin they'd come to for a summer holiday. There: her car, down at the end of the long yard. She got to the vehicle, her salvation, the keys fumbling in her shaky hand. Tortuously slowly, she started to unlock the door; but wait! Behind her, a figure becoming clearer in the shadows, pale moonlight reflecting off the blood-soaked axe raised above his head, the murderer! He raises his weapon into the air, as the stinging music grows louder and louder and louder, until Marissa finally sees him in the reflection off the cars window, when he brings the axe down and-

BOOM

"Jesus Christ!"

The TV went off, the room went dark, and the bowl of popcorn that had been sitting in Jason's lap was spilled onto the floor as he jumped in his seat. His heart was beating like a jack-hammer; it was only after a few moments of terror in the dark that he realized what the sound had been and what had happened to the lights.

"Damn fuse blew out..." It was a pretty common problem, really; his house was pretty old, and while his parents had meant to get some electricians to work on rewiring things for a while now, it was one of those problems that no one ever really got around to fixing. And so, with the slightest provocation, the fusebox blew. Meaning that, if he wanted to resume his activities for the night, he'd need to go outside, into the dark night, to fix it.

Unless Jason wanted to sit bored in the dark. After having just watched (most of) a movie about a killer who lurked in the dark.

Figuring that he'd rather be out in the dark for a few minutes rather than spending the rest of the night inside in the pitch blackness, Jason turned his phone back on (ignoring the additional text messages from his friends) and headed out into his backyard to open the fusebox.

As he opened it to take a look, however, a shiver went up his spine as he heard....

152.content:
Natalie let out another sigh as she stood behind the counter of the Scare Central Party Store. It was Halloween night, and while her friends were out having fun and going to all the great parties being held that night, she was stuck at work, waiting on customers she was certain were not going to show.

Natalie, at 20 years old, still loved the night more than any other day of the year. She enjoyed the scares, the creativity, and of course, dressing up. This Halloween was no exception. She was dressed in a costume she had made herself, as what she called a Victorian Vampire. She wore a black top with red leather straps wrapped around it just under the bust, complete with mesh, bunched sleeves to give it a little more flair. While no cleavage was shown, it was clear from the tightness of the top she was proudly showing off her size C bust. Her skirt was a mix of black and red satin trim, carefully ruffled into a classy look. The skirt stopped at mid thigh, showing off her long fishnet stocking clad legs with a pair of black heels to help show them off more. To complete the look, she had a red mini top hat placed upon her pixie cut, raven hair. Even if she wasn't out partying, she couldn't have let that costume go to waste.

“Some night, huh...” Her co-worker walked into the store. “Sorry I'm late, needed to get into costume.”

“No worries, Angie.” Natalie looked over at the 26 year old blonde, who in contrast to herself, had gone with a lazy approach to dressing. Angie wore a simple dalmatian onesie and black converses. The woman's golden locks spilled from the costume's hood, which naturally sported floppy ears at the top. “Nice costume.”

“Hey, the boss likes us wearing the merchandise.” Angie shrugged. “And this is the most comfortable thing I could find.” She walked over to counter to examine Natalie's costume closely. “Went all out this year I see.”

“It was supposed to be for going out partying tonight. But we see how that turned out.”

“Yeah, I was supposed to watch some horror movies with my boyfriend. Amazing how everyone else suddenly got sick on us.”

“They'll all be sick tomorrow... with hangovers...” Natalie shook her head as she walked around from behind the counter. “Can you watch the register a bit? I need to use the bathroom.”

“Take you time.” Angie said as she took Natalie's place. “Not like anyone's stopping by tonight.”

Natalie made her way towards the backroom door. She thought about how boring that night was going to be. How her Halloween would more and likely lack any kind of thrills or scares. It didn't cross her mind how wrong she would be.

What will Natalie find in the backroom and cause a lot of trouble tonight?
152.title: Natalie, stuck working the graveyard shift at a...

choices: An accident damages her costume before she even leaves the back room.
Angie starts acting strange as Natalie returns to the front counter.
1522.content:
On the way back from her bathroom break, Natalie decided she'd take a few minutes to browse the store's stock shelves. It wasn't like Angie'd be overwhelmed without her, after all. Bored as she was, even rummaging through surplus props and unpopular costumes sounded like a fun diversion.

At the beginning of the season, the storeroom had been crammed full of things ready to be sold off. Now, while not empty, it was definitely a lot easier to get through. For the licensed costumes, all the popular characters were gone, leaving behind the unpopular side characters and villains whose appeal had been over-estimated by their marketers. Long sold were the realistic, bloody cleavers and axes, now only cheap, neon plastic swords and daggers sat on the shelves collecting dust. Plastic spiders, cartoony ghost standees, etc. In short, it was a bunch of trash at this point. But it was different trash than what was out on the shelves, so Natalie was giving it a look.

She was just standing back up (she'd seen some gag "sexy janitor" costume on a bottom shelf- not really that funny, but she just wanted to make sure she'd seen right), when Natalie banged her head on the shelf above her. Beyond the throbbing in her head, the loud metal clang, and her own swearing, she heard the clatter of something falling to the ground. Looking over, she saw a piece of costume jewelry- a crimson gem pendant, sitting in a dull silver that seemed to sparkle in even the dim light of the back room. Natalie tapped her fingernail against the gem, only hearing the "clack" of hard plastic in return- but, wow, did it look real! In fact, a blood red gem on a subtle silver chain fit right in with the rest of her costume. Natalie looked around, despite knowing it was just her and Angie on duty- it wasn't like she'd get in trouble, right? A trinket, just wearing it for the night. She could give it back tomorrow, if anyone even said anything at all; if not, it'd just sit unsold in some warehouse for a year, so what was the harm. With a grin, she clasped the plastic necklace around her neck, surprised at how well it fit.

Of course, what Natalie couldn't have seen was the weak pulse of red light coming from the gem as she started back towards the store's main room. As such she had no idea what happened to cause her misfortune as....

A Ouija board and some candles.
154.content:
"Oh no...."

Sally, sitting by the window in her living room, was not very happy. She had been happy, yesterday, when she was preparing to go out and celebrate Halloween with her friends. She was worried that morning, when clouds started to roll in over the town. And now, with the rain pouring down, and the weather reports saying that it was only going to get worse, Sally was in complete despair.

Sally loved Halloween; getting to dress up in costume, getting to go around town with her friends, getting free candy. Some people might say that, as an adult, she should have outgrown these things, but that didn't matter to her! She was responsible, eager to try new things and expand her horizons, if a little overenthusiastic at times. Why shouldn't she get to celebrate a holiday how she liked? After all, it was only one night. But, while Sally felt good giving that explanation to people who frowned at her for her festivity, there was little she could say to make the clouds stop raining.

She made an interesting sight, like many people would on Halloween night. The room looked like a normal living room, the weatherman on the TV looked so normal as to be rather boring, but Sally herself was, of course, in costume. She was a fairy that year, not exactly scary but Sally was prone to doing whatever felt right. The green dress was a little short, close to her knees but still above, and it ended under her arms in a tube top. It was a little tight on her curvy frame, but the green looked nice against her light-brown hair. On her back, attached to the dress, was a pair of 'wings' made of a light but sturdy fabric, and she had a pair of accompanying shoes. Every part was glittery, which seemed a little gaudy, but Sally brushed it off. Literally. The glitter got everywhere, so Sally had to keep brushing it off.

Sally had just about given up for the night, not content but resigned to changing back into pj's and curling up in front of the TV, when she saw a pair of headlights blaring through the window as a car pulled into her driveway. It was hard to make out the figures past the lights, and two of them bolted to Sally's front door as soon as the car stopped moving. Sally jumped to her feet and hurried over as someone pounded on the door and her doorbell was pressed over and over again

"Trick-or-treat!"

"Yeah, Happy Halloween! Now let us in already!"

Sally started beaming, even as her guests pushed past her out of the rain. They were both friends of hers; the first, a black girl named Tanya. She was wearing a heavy jacket, but Sally could see a red skirt and red boots underneath, and a blue top with a Supergirl logo on it as she unzipped. Tanya was a smart girl, if a little shy, but she always had Sally's back! They were supposed to go out trick-or-treating, something that Sally had spent a long time convincing her friend to do with her, but this was just fine too!

With her was Amanda, white with dyed red shoulder length hair. She was outgoing, probably even more than Sally, but could go a little far sometimes. And not like Sally could, where she got tunnel vision and got too into something, but in an abrasive, insulting sort of way. Still, she (usually) knew enough to apologize when she really screwed up. Here, she was dressed in a devil costume; a pair of plastic red horns on a headband, a low cut red top and tight red shorts, and black gloves and boots.

Following close behind them was Jennifer, catching up just in time before Sally shut the door. She was Asian, taller than the rest of them and more muscular too; one of her hobbies was spending time at the gym. Her long black hair was pulled into a ponytail, getting wet in the rain, and she went for a very subtle vampire costume. Some might say "lazy" instead of "subtle", given that the costume seemed to just be a pair of fake vampire fangs and an all black outfit, including a shirt with a cartoon bat on the front. But, Jen was a reserved lady, and Sally appreciated even the small effort; she probably wouldn't have bothered at all if it wasn't to make Sally feel better.

"What are you guys doing here?" Sally asked, once everyone was inside and starting to dry off.

"Well, we knew how much you were looking to going out tonight, before it rained," Tanya said.

"So we figured we'd bring Halloween to you, if the weather was going to keep you from Halloween!" Amanda finished.

"It's not like we planned on doing anything without you tonight," Jen added, and only put up a little resistance when Sally went to hug her, and then the rest of them in turn.

"You girls are the greatest!" Sally said, before frowning. "I don't really have anything planned, though..."

"Say no more!" said Amanda, and Sally grinned, eyes widening, as Amanda reached into a bag she had brought and pulled out...
154.title: Sally, whose Halloween plans got ruined by the ...

choices: Tanya spilled her drink onto Sally by accident.
The power went out.
There was a loud knocking at the door.
1541.content:
Sally could see on the box that the movie was aptly titled "Town of Terror," and she grinned. "Oh my God! I didn't know that was out on DVD!"

Amanda smiled and nodded. "Yep. Came out earlier this week. I saw it in the store, and remembered you saying you missed it in theater's, so..." Amanda trailed off as Sally bounced over and grabbed the box from her hand.

"Thank you, thank you, thank you!"

Tanya also smiled, as Jen held up another plastic bag. Sally could see cans of soda and bags of chips through the transparent material. "We stopped for snacks on the way over," she explained, "they were cleaned out on candy though..."

"Not a problem!" Sally said, taking the bowl of candy in her other hand. It was meant to go to any trick-or-treaters that showed up before she left, but the deluge outside had made that point useless. No, as the four costumed girls filed into Sally's living room, their host popping the disc into the player as Jen walked into the kitchen with a bowl of popcorn, they all decided that they were going to indulge themselves.

--------------------------


"Well," John Marshall said, pulling his car into the driveway of his girlfriend's house, "I'm sure glad we lost that creepy hitchhiker who was following us."

"You're telling me," Jane Watson said, arms folded over her chest, "I'm shivering just thinking about him!"

John grinned at her as they left the car and walked to her front door. "Would it made you feel better if I stayed the night?"

His girlfriend huffed, and exasperated smile creeping onto her face. "Nice try, pal. I'll see you tomorrow."

Amanda, lying across the seat of an armchair, feigned gagging. Sally giggled as she lied on the floor in front of the couch., but shushed her as the boyfriend's car pulled away from the house. The camera cut to a shadowy silhouette walking down the road, and Tanya whined. Jen, sitting next to her on the couch, put a hand on her shoulder, which seemed to calm her down some. The camera cut to the bathroom, showing Jane from the knee down climbing into the shower, her clothes crumpled on the tile floor.

Jane let the hot water rush over her, steam rising as the dirt was scoured from every pore on her body. She was humming; softly, but the acoustics of the bathroom made it seem louder to her. Loud enough that she couldn't hear the lock on her door being forced, anyway.

"Oh no..." Tanya whispered, and Sally shushed her this time, getting a glare from Jen.

Softly, the door to her bathroom opened. Jane felt a cold breeze, but just turned the water up hotter in response. The hitchhiker could see her silhouetted through the shower curtain. Slowly, he raised an arm- a shiv held tight in his gloved fist! Slowly, he reached for the curtain. Jane frowned: was that... breathing she heard? Suddenly, the shower curtain swung open!
